title: Poundworld profits more than double as UK consumers continue to count the pennies
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Mon, Sep 14, 2015, 12:02 BST - UK Markets close in 4 hrs 28 mins Poundworld profits more than double as UK consumers continue to count the pennies By Julia Bradshaw | Telegraph – 28 minutes ago 22.55 +0.03 
The discount retailer is growing fast following its takeover by US private equity group TPG Capital 
Poundworld's profits more than doubled last year as British consumers continued to keep tight control of their purse strings. 
The discount retailer said operating profits rose 130pc to £14.6m in the year to March 31, following 12 months of record trading. 
Like-for-like sales growth averaged 5.6pc over the year as Poundworld opened 38 stores, boosting turnover by just over a fifth to £422.3m. 
The year was also significant for Poundworld as it culminated in its takeover by US-based private equity group TPG Capital in May for £150m in cash . 
Poundworld's founder, Chris Edwards, who started out in a market stall in Yorkshire in 1974, and his son Chris Edwards Junior, who has worked at the company since he was 15, became multi-millionaires overnight. 
They are both believed to have kept a minority stake in the business. 
TPG (Taiwan OTC: 6521.TWO - news ) 's promise to invest in Poundworld appears to have started already. 
The private equity firm said it had injected new funding into Poundworld to accelerate the store expansion programme to more than 60 stores a year from 2016. 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) also plans to upgrade the retailer's distribution facilities and operating systems. 
Poundworld's debt pile is also shrinking, falling by one-third to £10.6m in the year. 
Chris Edwards, chief executive of Poundworld Retail, said: "We have seen a record financial year and one of landmark progress for the company. 
“We expect the year ahead to be one of development and consolidation that includes investment into a new 500,000 square foot warehousing facility next to our current head office and the replacement of our existing retail data system. 
"We’re confident that these changes will provide a strong platform for rapid growth over the next three years bringing our proposition of convenience and value to even more customers across the UK.” 
Poundworld is the UK’s second biggest single-price discount retailer and serves more than two million customers every week. The company operates under two brands: Poundworld and Bargain Buys. 
Bargain chains have enjoyed a renaissance since the recession hit, becoming one of the fastest-growing sectors in retail. 
This fast-growth profile, coupled with favourable stock market conditions and cheap debt, has led to a wave of new listings. Rival stores Poundland and B&M Bargains have both floated on the London stock market over the past two years. 
The sector also appears to be in consolidation mode. In August, Poundland's £55m takeover of its rival 99p Stores was provisionally cleared by the UK's competition watchdog after an in-depth probe into the deal. 
The watchdog said that while only one major single-priced retailer - Poundworld - would remain after the deal, the merged company would still face competition from other discounters including B&M, Home Bargains, Wilko and Bargain Buys as well as supermarket chains including Tesco (Xetra: 852647 - news ) and Asda.
